Bomb Scare Forces
Library Evacuation
by Tom McNamara

Ganesh Rarnachandran

Evacuated late-night patrons of the M.S.E. library who were forced to leave when the library recieved several bomb
threats Sunday and Monday.

At 7:15 p.m. on Sunday,
February 16, and again at 7:05
and 8:58 p.m. on Monday,
February 17, the Milton S.
Eisenhower Library received
telephone threats that a bomb
had been planted in the library.
The perpetrator has not been
found,
although
both
Baltimore city police, and the
University security have been
working on the case.
According to Robert Larking, Manager of Hopkins
security, Sunday night, a caller
whose voice was described as
that of a male in his twenties,
allegedly told an employee at
the library that he "hated" that
establishment, and that he had
planted a bomb on A-level.
Campus security and city police
were notified and the building

was evacuated and searched,
but no such device was found.
Patrons were allowed to reenter at 8:30, and MSE remained open until midnight without
further incident, according to
Larkin.
On Monday, two more bomb
threats were allegedly received
at the library, according to
campus security. At 8:05 p.m.,
a caller, again described as a
young male, allegedly stated
that "another bomb" had been
planted and made other
remarks which were unsuitable
for publication and very hostile
to the library, according to
Larkin. The library was immediately evacuated and
searched and again no bomb
was found, and the facility was
reopened at 8:25.

Students Injured on
Outdoors Club Trip
Two Hopkins students were
seriously injured in a car accident last Sunday when their car
skidded off the road and slid on
its side down an embankment
in West Virginia.
The two seriously injured
students, Freshman Karen Nixon and Junior Ken Walsh, were
returning from a caving expedition with the Hopkins Outdoors Club when the accident
occured.
According to Outdoors Club
Publicity Director Paul Frascione, Nixon and Walsh were
the two front seat occupants of
a rental car containing three
other members of the club.
None of the other riders suffered serious injury in the
accident.
Frascione said that Nixon
received a compression fracture
or two lower vertebrae during
the accident and underwent
surgery soon thereafter. According to Frascione, she is

recovering quickly and "the
doctors are not worried."
Frascione added that Nixon
will likely be released from the
hospital sometime next week.
According to Frascione,
Walsh, the secretary-treasurer
of the club, underwent exploratory abdominal surgery
after the crash, but was found
to have no serious internal injuries. Walsh also suffered a
broken cheek bone in the accident. Like Nixon, Walsh is expected to be released soon.
Frascione said that this
time, the police in West
Virginia are treating the crash
as a "no fault accident caused
by the slippery conditions."
According to Frascione, both
Nixon and Walsh were wearing
seatbelts during the crash and
were assisted for about one
hour by a Hopkins EMT and
two Hopkins Advance First Aid
certificate holders before the
ambulances arrived.

Does Winning Count?
If, as the old saying goes, close only
counts in horseshoes and hand grenades,
then even actually winning may not
always count in politics.
At least that's the way the pro-South
African divestment forces must be feeling after Tuesday's student referendum.
They may have won the vote, but
evidently they didn't do so convincingly
enough to win over the Student Council.
To recap a bit, students were asked to
vote on whether the University should
"fully divest itself of its holdings in companies which do business in South
Africa." About 730 people voted—a
remarkably high turn-out considering the
vote was called hastily and only one issue
was being decided.(As a point of comparison, only 685 votes were cast in the
Student Council Presidential run-off last
spring.) Well over half of those
voting-56 percent—favored divestment. In all, 409 people voted for divestment, 73 more than voted for Paul Kadri
last year.
The referendum was called, Council
members said two weeks ago, to gauge
student feeling on the issue of South
African investments. Although it was
never stated openly, the clear implication

was that if students endorsed divestment,
the Council would too. That was a
thoroughly reasonable position, since the
Council was not elected to deliberate on
political issues, and generally should
avoid such matters.
And yet, despite the endorsement of
divestment by the student body, the
Council refused to sign the so-called
"Points of Unity" the Hopkins Coalition for a Free South Africa has been
pushing.
Why? Well, there are probably several
reasons. First, University Treasurer
Riggs Griffith must have convinced
several Council members that divestment
is a bad idea. Second, some members
believe that since people who favor
divestment were more likely to vote than
those who oppose it, the results were
essentially meaningless. And last, there
were no doubt some members who were
simply intransigent, and who were going
to ignore the vote totals no matter what.
In any event, it is a pity the Council
did not endorse divestment. Having quite
rightly declared the matter beyond its
competence, the Council had referred the
issue to the voters. It should have listened to what they said.

When the faculty and the Trustees and

ourselves in the rear. Hopkins may well

but it is also a university in dire need of
a thorough re-evaluation.
To go step-by-step: the faculty is narrow and myopic in its devotion to
academic research and is widely perceived as caring little (if at all) about
undergraduates; the students are a selfish
lot who cannot seem to conceive of
anything more important than getting into medical school; and the administration is just generally incompetent.

traditional hostility to Spring Fair. The
faculty has always hated the Fair, principally because its precious academic
research cannot be interrupted for all

increases, but because of a proposal to
close the Hut. In other words, what

student bodies in the country.

innumerable goofs in organizing the dormitory telephone service, offended the

isn't hopeless. An effort can be made to
increase the stress placed on teaching

future.

prestigious name won't do anyone any
good. Instead, we must all candidly
assess the University's(many) problems,
and seek ways to solve them.
As Hopkins enters its twelfth decade,
it would do well to make today less an
occasion for celebration, and more an
opportunity for recommitment.

To the Editor:
As many readers may know,
the Men's Varsity Basketball
team played a superb game this
past Saturday as they upset nationally ranked Washington
College. The game was one of
the more exciting I've ever been
to, Division III or otherwise;
but in one aspect, it was also
one of the more disappointing.

season, settled in for what most
people expected to be a blowout for Washington College.

fans,
supporters
from

more than a bit foolish, late in
the game, on my team's home
court, when after every lead
change Hopkins fans were outcheered by fans who had driven

see the game.

mistaken for Division I. There

thundering slam dunks. This
does not mean the game lacks
excitement. Just ask any
Washington College fan, willing to commit a large part of a
Saturday night to support their
team. Perhaps Division III
basketball is more human and
down to earth than Division I,
with solid shooting and defense
emphasized over potent
fastbreaks and flashy offenses.

can provide spectators with enjoyment. Those few Hopkins
fans in attendance Saturday
night can attest to that. I congratulate the Men's Basketball
team on an outstanding win
and a solid performance all
season long. It's a shame so few
Hopkins supporters caught the
excitement.

The first major exhibition of

United States opened at the

Sunday, February 9. Schlemmer, though not well-known in

works between 1911 and 1942.
The exhibition will be in
Baltimore until April 6; then it
will move on to New York, San
Francisco and Minneapolis.
Arnold L. Lehman and
Brenda Richardson, cocurators for the exhibition
spent over five years gathering
the 240 works of art which
make up one of the Museum's
most ambitious events. The
show contains collections of
Schlemmer's art loaned by the
Stuttegart Museum, the
Schlemmer Family Estate and
many private collectors in the
United Stats.
Schlemmer's work is difficult
to characterize because it
belongs to no medium or
school. He was a sculptor,
choreographer, and playdirector as well as a painter. He
was called to be the master of
sculpture, mural painting and
stage workshops at the
Bauhaus, the famous hot-bed
of German art which thrived
before World War II. After
1933, his work was suppressed
by the Nazis and he had to take
a menial job until his death in

Schlemmer's works are

by
populated
humanoid figures. They range
from figures which seem to be
merely combinations of spheres
and cylinders to fully-developed
mannequin-like figures. Some
of his less-human figures may
have one or two appendages
shaped nothing like an arm or
a leg. One room in the exhibition contains figures with bats
or metal rings for arms and
where there should be legs,
there is only what looks like
funnel going into a point. On
one wall, there are paintings of
these figures and in front of
another wall there are life-size
sculptures of the same figures.
These oddly shaped and proportioned figures show Schlemmer's fascination with the way
the body appears from one
position to another, from a
state of action to a state of rest.
As a choreographer, he was
very sensitive to these shifts. He

refines this fascination and
develops a theme when he pares
down these unorthodox shapes
into a uniform figure.
There is a funny story behind
the similar figures which
populate most of Schlemmer's
work. Schlemmer and several
freinds all shaved their heads as
a joke. Unfortunately for the
Bauhaus master, his hair did
not grow back. However,
Schlemmer used it to his advantage and, it seems, used his own
head as the model for his
figures. The figures in many of
his paintings look very much
like store-mannequins without
clothes or wigs. Schlemmer
stressed the similarities between
humans as moving forms. The
differences or facial features
and gender are done away with
because Schlemmer's figures
have no expressions or
genitalia.
It is not easy to reduce
Shlemmer's work to some
message. Though he worked
during a time of great social

and political turmoil in Germany, Schlemmer didn't concentrate on political themes
often.
The thing which attracted
this writer most to Oskar
Schlemmer's art is the unique
way he portrays motion. As a
choreographer, he had to be
aware of how the human form
bends and twists in motion. In
his paintings and his sculptuits,
he captures figures at specific
points in their action, so that
while each figure seems to be
very much in motion, it also
seems to be perfectly still.

the book appears to be an attempt to prove the narrator
sane.

history, the narrator, identified

childhood. The reader is
presented with an extremely
precocious and neurotic little

Does Winning Count?
If, as the old saying goes, close only
counts in horseshoes and hand grenades,
then even actually winning may not
always count in politics.
At least that's the way the pro-South
African divestment forces must be feeling after Tuesday's student referendum.
They may have won the vote, but
evidently they didn't do so convincingly
enough to win over the Student Council.
To recap a bit, students were asked to
vote on whether the University should
"fully divest itself of its holdings in companies which do business in South
Africa." About 730 people voted—a
remarkably high turn-out considering the
vote was called hastily and only one issue
was being decided.(As a point of comparison, only 685 votes were cast in the
Student Council Presidential run-off last
spring.) Well over half of those
voting-56 percent—favored divestment. In all, 409 people voted for divestment, 73 more than voted for Paul Kadri
last year.
The referendum was called, Council
members said two weeks ago, to gauge
student feeling on the issue of South
African investments. Although it was
never stated openly, the clear implication

was that if students endorsed divestment,
the Council would too. That was a
thoroughly reasonable position, since the
Council was not elected to deliberate on
political issues, and generally should
avoid such matters.
And yet, despite the endorsement of
divestment by the student body, the
Council refused to sign the so-called
"Points of Unity" the Hopkins Coalition for a Free South Africa has been
pushing.
Why? Well, there are probably several
reasons. First, University Treasurer
Riggs Griffith must have convinced
several Council members that divestment
is a bad idea. Second, some members
believe that since people who favor
divestment were more likely to vote than
those who oppose it, the results were
essentially meaningless. And last, there
were no doubt some members who were
simply intransigent, and who were going
to ignore the vote totals no matter what.
In any event, it is a pity the Council
did not endorse divestment. Having quite
rightly declared the matter beyond its
competence, the Council had referred the
issue to the voters. It should have listened to what they said.

Commemoration Day
When the faculty and the Trustees and
those ever-present "distinguished
guests" all get together later today to
commemorate the 110th anniversary of
the University, everybody will no doubt
be cheerful and happy and optimistic and
say wonderful things about this great institution that stands at the forefront of
American higher education and is a
leader in research efforts and was the
first true university in America and is a
monument to the legacy of Johns
Hopkins and fields a great lacrosse team
and has a really neat clock tower
and
Well, we have a word of caution: This
is not the time to be patting ourselves on
the back, it is the time to be kicking
ourselves in the rear. Hopkins may well
be a highly-respected pillar of academe,
but it is also a university in dire need of
a thorough re-evaluation.
To go step-by-step: the faculty is narrow and myopic in its devotion to
academic research and is widely perceived as caring little (if at all) about
undergraduates; the students are a selfish
lot who cannot seem to conceive of
anything more important than getting into medical school; and the administration is just generally incompetent.
As an example, take the faculty's
traditional hostility to Spring Fair. The
faculty has always hated the Fair, principally because its precious academic
research cannot be interrupted for all
of—one day! That's really why the Fair
no longer has music on Friday.
The students are not much better. The
biggest student protest in our memory

occurred not because of South African
investment or alcohol policy or tuition
increases, but because of a proposal to
close the Hut. In other words, what
scares Hopkins students most is the idea
that they won't be able to study at 4 a.m.
Indeed, we are known nationwide as one
of the most boring, overly-professional
student bodies in the country.
And as for the administration? Well,
where should we begin? Just this year
alone, it has come to light that the
powers that be were duped into signing
a ridiculous food service contract, made
innumerable goofs in organizing the dormitory telephone service, offended the
neighbors and generally contiliued to
foul up the situation at WJHU.
But having sounded sufficiently
lugubrious, let us add that the situation
isn't hopeless. An effort can be made to
increase the stress placed on teaching
(from nil to slight, at least) when awarding tenure. Similarly, we can try to
recruit high school seniors with strong
records in extracurricular activities, and
with interests in fields other than the
sciences. And perhaps even the administration can admit its checkered
past, and resolve to stay on its toes in the
future.
Our point is that resting on our
prestigious name won't do anyone any
good. Instead, we must all candidly
assess the University's(many) problems,
and seek ways to solve them.
As Hopkins enters its twelfth decade,
it would do well to make today less an
occasion for celebration, and more an
opportunity for recommitment.

Every now and then, The
Hopkins News-Letter manages
to be at once puerile, inaccurate, and insulting. On behalf
of the Editorial Board of The
Goucher Quindecim, may I say
that that unappealing combination, most often found in the

coeducational
Goucher's

Thanks a lot.

wrote it, to the editor who let

To the Editor:
As many readers may know,
the Men's Varsity Basketball
team played a superb game this
past Saturday as they upset nationally ranked Washington
College. The game was one of
the more exciting I've ever been
to, Division III or otherwise;
but in one aspect, it was also
one of the more disappointing.
A full gym, for the first time all
season, settled in for what most
people expected to be a blowout for Washington College.
That the game turned out differently came as a chagrin to
more than three quarters of the
fans,
supporters
from
Washington College. I felt
more than a bit foolish, late in
the game, on my team's home
court, when after every lead
change Hopkins fans were outcheered by fans who had driven
over an hour in poor weather to
see the game.

mistaken for Division I. There
are few NBA-style lay-ups or
thundering slam dunks. This
does not mean the game lacks
excitement. Just ask any
Washington College fan, willing to commit a large part of a
Saturday night to support their
team. Perhaps Division III
basketball is more human and
down to earth than Division I,
with solid shooting and defense
emphasized over potent
fastbreaks and flashy offenses.
Yet both brands of basketball
can provide spectators with enjoyment. Those few Hopkins
fans in attendance Saturday
night can attest to that. I congratulate the Men's Basketball
team on an outstanding win
and a solid performance all
season long. It's a shame so few
Hopkins supporters caught the
excitement.
Jeff Gordon

by Claude loss°
The first major exhibition of
Oskar Schlemmer's work in the
United States opened at the
Baltimore Museum of Art on
Sunday, February 9. Schlemmer, though not well-known in
the States, was a versatile and
prolific German modernist who
produced many innovative
works between 1911 and 1942.
The exhibition will be in
Baltimore until April 6; then it
will move on to New York, San
Francisco and Minneapolis.
Arnold L. Lehman and
Brenda Richardson, cocurators for the exhibition
spent over five years gathering
the 240 works of art which
make up one of the Museum's
most ambitious events. The
show contains collections of
Schlemmer's art loaned by the
Stuttegart Museum, the
Schlemmer Family Estate and
many private collectors in the
United Stats.
Schlemmer's work is difficult
to characterize because it
belongs to no medium or
school. He was a sculptor,
choreographer, and playdirector as well as a painter. He
was called to be the master of
sculpture, mural painting and
stage workshops at the
Bauhaus, the famous hot-bed
of German art which thrived
before World War II. After
1933, his work was suppressed
by the Nazis and he had to take
a menial job until his death in
1942. This suppression and
forced anonymity is a big
reason why his work is so unfamiliar to Americans.
Schlemmer's work spans
several periods, beginning in
the early Cubist period (he contributed to an exhibit which included the works of Braque,
Gleizes, Kandinsky, and others)
in 1911 to his last productions
during the Second World War.
never
art
Schlemmer's
"matured" into one style. His
work is unified by a theme, not
a style. Though a few of his early landscapes show a great
similarity to the Cubist efforts
of Braque and Picasso he soon
moved away from that to concentrate on the human figure.
Schlemmer's works are
peculiar
by
populated
humanoid figures. They range
from figures which seem to be
merely combinations of spheres
and cylinders to fully-developed
mannequin-like figures. Some
of his less-human figures may
have one or two appendages
shaped nothing like an arm or
a leg. One room in the exhibition contains figures with bats
or metal rings for arms and
where there should be legs,
there is only what looks like
funnel going into a point. On
one wall, there are paintings of
these figures and in front of
another wall there are life-size
sculptures of the same figures.
These oddly shaped and proportioned figures show Schlemmer's fascination with the way
the body appears from one
position to another, from a
state of action to a state of rest.
As a choreographer, he was
very sensitive to these shifts. He

refines this fascination and
develops a theme when he pares
down these unorthodox shapes
into a uniform figure.
There is a funny story behind
the similar figures which
populate most of Schlemmer's
work. Schlemmer and several
freinds all shaved their heads as
a joke. Unfortunately for the
Bauhaus master, his hair did
not grow back. However,
Schlemmer used it to his advantage and, it seems, used his own
head as the model for his
figures. The figures in many of
his paintings look very much
like store-mannequins without
clothes or wigs. Schlemmer
stressed the similarities between
humans as moving forms. The
differences or facial features
and gender are done away with
because Schlemmer's figures
have no expressions or
genitalia.
It is not easy to reduce
Shlemmer's work to some
message. Though he worked
during a time of great social

and political turmoil in Germany, Schlemmer didn't concentrate on political themes
often.
The thing which attracted
this writer most to Oskar
Schlemmer's art is the unique
way he portrays motion. As a
choreographer, he had to be
aware of how the human form
bends and twists in motion. In
his paintings and his sculptuits,
he captures figures at specific
points in their action, so that
while each figure seems to be
very much in motion, it also
seems to be perfectly still.
This reporter may be totally
wrong in his interpretation of
Oskar Schlemmer's art, but the
reader will never know until he
goes to the museum to find out
for himself. The Baltimore
Museum of Art is open from
10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. on
Tuesday through Friday, 6:00
to 10:00 p.m. on Thursdays and
11:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on
Saturdays and Sundays. Admission is free to students.

specter of nuclear war ever

comes to grips with this brutal
reality. This is not a lighthearted book; The Nuclear Age
is a horror story, not in the

keeps scaring the reader even

sane.

history, the narrator, identified

childhood. The reader is
presented with an extremely
precocious and neurotic little
